author: treyzania
content: not everything can be measured in as simple categories as "centralized" or "decentralized"

author: treyzania
content: by that kind of logic you could say bitcoin's reward halving is centralized

author: hikariws
content:
Notice I said more centralized, in the way that it's not a binary choice. I mean that it makes the network require some sort of leadership to coordinate the bomb delay. On every upgrade that changes anything, the bomb may be delayed too, which makes the upgrade fork more prone to succeed and a possible fork against it to halt. So that, if part of the community splits against the upgrade, the dissidents also need to coordinate into their own upgrade to delay the bomb. Under a social fork, it makes harder for the smaller group as it forces them to coordinate too.

BTC halving was set when it started and it happens automatically, no need of a leadership to coordinate it or against it. AFAIK its behavior was never changed. And also it has its own feature, which is decrease currency production over time into a limited total amount. Difficulty bomb has no useful feature on its own.

author: ajsutton
content: Stagnation != decentralisation.  The difficulty bomb means that stagnation is not an option. The choice of what to do about that is still fully decentralised.  It could just as easily be argued that Bitcoin is more centralised because the "no change" option has such a strong bias towards it, giving the original developers centralised control.

author: ajsutton
content: I'm not sure that's really true, but it's just as good an argument as saying that regular upgrades are a form of centralisation.  It's really just that stagnation and centralisation are completely different axis.

author: symme7ry
content: I'm looking for a detailed analysis of how censorship (by a group of validators) would be dealt with by ETH2. Is there a good writeup on this? Specifically I'm wondering: If a censorship attack is happening, how would the censoring validators be identified (so we could slash them)? I assume there's no automatic way to identify and slash censorers, so it would require community coordination. If you tried to slash any particular validator, couldn't they easily say "I just happened to not include the censored transactions in my block for <other reasons>"? How could we have high confidence that those reasons weren't credible?

author: trent_vanepps
content:
the broader community historically understands hard forks to be something contentious, and also something where they end up with 2 coins with financial value. this is improving lately, but the misconception persists. IMO it's easier to change the term used than explain "no this is a non-contentious hard fork"

(hopefully I can double convince you)

author: sky.cactus
content: There is no formal process defined.  IN fact, I would argue *against* defining a formal process because such a process can be gamed and we *specifically* are reserving the process for situations that *cannot* be automatically dealt with, which weakly implies that a well defined process may not be possible.

author: sky.cactus
content: The gist though is in the case of blatant censorship, you can lead with a threat that "anyone who continues to censor X will be slashed via user activated slashing".  If censorship continues at that point, people don't have a legitimate excuse (in the rare case they did have an excuse before hand).

author: symme7ry
content: OK, that makes sense. Am I right that censorship in PoS would require > 50% of stake just like in PoW, and would look essentially the same? Like if a validator proposes a block that contains txns that the censorers don't like, the censoring cartel orphans it and only builds on chains where it's orphaned, and they win because they get to propose more than 50% of blocks?

author: sky.cactus
content: I think so, though someone else may be able to answer better than I on that.  You need 66% to achieve finality I believe, but if >50% are censoring the remaining honest validators will follow along I think.
